entry.title: The Future of Ops: Scaling Fast, Higher Security With AI
entry.content:
In my two decades of helping organizations modernize their technology landscape, I‚Äôve observed that one principle never changes ‚Äî the faster we innovate, the more complex our operations get. The shift towards cloud adoption, continuous delivery, and agility has become unwavering, but it also reveals the fundamental gaps in traditional IT operations. 

For this reason, I firmly believe the future belongs to those who implement an AI-First Ops strategy - not just to automate workflows but also for integrating intelligence and adaptability into the core operations. So, just ‚Äòdoing things faster‚Äô won't cut it anymore. We need to take more intelligent, data-driven decisions that equally consider speed, security, and scalability without compromising quality. 

From Automation to Intelligence 

For years, businesses were dependent on rule-based automation for reactive systems. It helped execute predefined tasks with "if-this-then-that" logic rules, but lacked some perspective. This worked well when the infrastructures were simpler, but with today‚Äôs cloud-native, hybrid, and distributed environments, it calls for extra action. Hence, nowadays more than 80% of executives leverage AI-based automation for their business processes. 

In an AI-First Ops model, we shift from rule-based systems to adaptive learning ecosystems. AI consistently examines event data, metrics, and logs across the organization to predict failure, identify anomalies, and even address the issues before they lead to consequences. 

Machine learning algorithms and models are now capable of connecting millions of events instantly within seconds, which usually takes hours or days. This is about more than just speed; it‚Äôs about converting data into valuable insights, which allows enterprises to drive innovation proactively and confidently. 

Integrating the Three Core Elements: Speed, Security, and Scalability 

Every CIO and CTO I have worked with encounters the same trio of obstacles ‚Äì how to expand without falling out of control, and how to speed up the delivery without sacrificing security. The AI-First Ops model provides a structure to balance these conflicting demands. 

Speed: Latest Golden Standard in Innovation  

In today‚Äôs high-tech landscape, speed provides organizations with a competitive edge. Clients demand instant updates, intuitive experiences, and flawless uptime. Yet, traditional IT workflows struggle to thrive because they‚Äôre still response-driven. 

AI helps predict these issues before they even happen. Just imagine your AI-driven system recognizing performance degradation issues hours before a technical failure and rectifying issues without manual intervention or automatically reallocating resources. Well, that‚Äôs not a futuristic trend; it‚Äôs what modern AIOps platforms help with. 

In one project based on enterprise transformation, I observed that AI-powered predictive maintenance reduces resolution times by 50% and minimizes incident frequency by 40%. This helped teams with additional time and higher focus on innovation. 

That‚Äôs the core of AI-First Ops: restoring focus and efficiency.  

Security: Smarter Resilience in Action 

As organizations are leveraging remote and multi-cloud models, there‚Äôs an exponential rise in attack surface. Yet many businesses find security as an additional part rather than an integrated feature. This needs to change. 

AI helps integrate intelligence directly into resilience. By examining behavioral patterns, AI-powered systems can spot anomalies that alert to possible threats. 

At Radixweb, we‚Äôve helped organizations deploy AI-driven adaptive cybersecurity frameworks. These cutting-edge systems produce prioritized alerts for analysts, automatically isolate suspicious workflows, and evaluate incidents based on contextual risks. 

This is where AI stands out ‚Äî not just in solving issues proactively but also in building systems to predicting them. It transforms security into an adaptive process that reacts as quickly as attackers. And for tech leaders, it translates into the freedom to innovate fearlessly. 

Scalability: Expansion made Seamless 

Scaling a system is not a Herculean task. Scaling them smartly ‚Äî that‚Äôs the real challenge. As operations scale, the visibility often diminishes. Teams might face complexity spirals, an unpredictable rise in workloads, and lose control of cloud expenses. 

AI-first Ops model restores clarity via data-based scalability. AI models help businesses grow, adjust workloads, forecast demands, and even enhance resource allocation based on utilization patterns. 

I worked with a global enterprise that used AI to predict seasonal traffic trends. So, instead of overallocating resources just to be safe, their systems now scale automatically in real time, saving nearly 35% in yearly cloud expenses while maintaining efficiency. 

This kind of intelligence not only minimizes cost, but also ensures resilient growth. 

Embedding an AI-Driven Ops Mindset 

Integrating AI technology alone won‚Äôt help organizations achieve ‚ÄòAI-first tag‚Äô. It‚Äôs a cognitive shift ‚Äî one that combines people, process, and data. Over the years, I‚Äôve seen the organizations who follow these key principles that successful adopters: 

  • Unify your Data First 
    Your AI systems are only as good as the data it learns from. Centralize your operational data including logs, traces, metrics into a single observability layer. Because scattered data results in scattered intelligence. 
  • Design Continuous Learning Loops 
    AI should evolve with time. You can integrate feedback loops from incident resolutions, system productivity, and user behavior to keep models adaptive, accurate, and on track.  
  • Integrate AI into DevOps Pipelines 
    Don‚Äôt just consider AIOps as a standalone function. Integrate it throughout the CI/CD processes for automated testing, validation, and rollback. Unifying DevOps and AIOps sustains a continuous learning and improvement ecosystem. 
  • Prioritize Explainability 
    As tech leaders, we have to believe AI decisions, however, this belief majorly comes from transparency. You can leverage explainable AI (XAI) to ensure your teams understand why some models make certain suggestions. 
  • Team Empowerment 
    Upskilling is the most crucial part of empowering your team. You can help and encourage your IT teams to go from administrators to strategists ‚Äî experts who can easily interpret AI insights and drive automation with business goals. 

AI-First Ops Strategy: Unlocking Business Impact Beyond IT  

An AI-First Ops strategy is not just limited to IT ‚Äî it‚Äôs a growth catalyst. The influence goes far beyond traditional performance indicators: 

  • Adherence to compliance protocols solidifies since AI is consistently enforcing audit readiness and governance. 
  • Innovation accelerates because teams can iterate faster and are free to experiment. 
  • There's a reduction in operational costs due to the automation of redundant tasks and resources optimization. 
  • Client experience improves as digital solutions get more responsive and downtime reduces. 

Paving the Way for Autonomous Enterprises 

I often say that AI-First Ops marks the beginning of a significant transformation towards autonomous businesses‚Äîa future where AI-based systems are self-learning, self-healing, self-improving, and self-guarding. 

However, this self-governance doesn‚Äôt refer to a lack of control. It relates to intelligent control, where human knowledge drives AI accuracy. The objective isn‚Äôt substituting your employees, it's empowering them.  

As business leaders, it's our role to balance these aspects ‚Äî speed, security, and scalability ‚Äî with an objective. AIOps allows us to align these elements, ensuring faster execution, secure processes, and higher scalability.  

The businesses that strike the perfect equilibrium will pioneer the next era of digital leadership. And I firmly believe that those embracing the AI-First Ops mindset will set the benchmark for the future.

entry.title: Re: Set time account booking end date after account valid...
entry.content:
Hi @MeiBoon50 

There are 2 ways to do this extension in time account. 

Configuration 1:-  Setting the "Account Booking Offset [Months]" to 12 in the time account always set the time account booking until be always 12 months extension compare to the account valid till.  

Configuration 2:- Creating the interim rule to extend the current calendar year to 12 months, which will extend only the Booking until date.

In both the conditions only booking end date will be extended and time account validity will be only for the current calendar year.

Above mentioned configurations are system driven approach and it allows employees to utilise the balance till the booking end date even though the time account validity is in past. 

Configuration 1 will set whenever time account is created, no need any additional set up or run. 

Configuration 2 has to be triggered from the time off calendar. 

Thanks & Regards

Arun
